> Disclaimer: Opinions expressed are solely my own and do not express the views or opinions of my employer.


## Bio

Starting in web design, I have spent a career growing my skills as a UX Designer and Front-End Engineer while continuing to push myself further by broaden my engineering skills.

Much of my career experience includes working with design teams and/or building design systems, in addition to working on feature-rich web applications for companies like Getty Images, BestBuy, REI, AppDirect, Microsoft and Alaska Airlines. Aside from my development experience, I have lead [Bootcamp-style Front-End Engineering courses](https://www.codefellows.org/blog/a-night-with-ux-engineer-dale-sande/), authored multiple [online presentations](https://speakerdeck.com/anotheruiguy) and publications, produced two online courses for Treehouse, and organized the efforts of local meetup groups, Seattle Sass, Refresh Seattle, and now, Seattle-WC..

HTML, CSS/Sass, responsive mobile-first development, accessibility and web optimization, all my bag. Professional growth has brought me to a point where I have been committed to having a deeper understanding of full-stack JavaScript web app development.

I possess the engineering experience required for working on any scale of projects, such as software development life cycles, coding standards, code reviews, distributed revision control systems (Git/Github/Bitbucket/Gitlab), continuous test/build/deploy, and production support.


## Building Design Systems

Design Systems are all the rage now, but this really all started a good number of years ago. Working on projects for the past 15 years I have always looked for ways to reduce duplication across projects and teams.

The hardest part of realizing this dream is the tech. Time and time again I have repeated patterns of development in the space of this stack of the other. Rails. Sass. Backbone/Marionette, Angular. Riot. React, etc ... at one time or another the work was the same but the framework was the difference. Every time I built a new thing, I hated it because I couldn't take it with me. The core of building a design system is it's ability to apply to all projects, but with each execution I was painted into a corner.

That's all history now. The future is much better!

## HTML Custom Elements

The dream has been here for a while, but the reality is here today. [HTML Custom Elements](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components/Using_custom_elements) are available [everywhere](https://caniuse.com/custom-elementsv1). Sure, IE doesn't support it, but [IE is dead](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-365-blog/microsoft-365-apps-say-farewell-to-internet-explorer-11-and/ba-p/1591666), so it's time to move on.

New to custom elements? No worries, it's one of my goals to use this blog as a resource for new comers as well as experienced developers. These are amazing times and there are so many new opportunities for this new tech and it's only going to get better.

Aside from that I hope to have great content in here for all things front-end. As I have learned, as I know and as I learn new things, I hope to get updates in here as much as possible!
